oai_dc:dc.dc:description: <jats:p>Seagrass meadows are critical ecosystems, and they are among the most threatened habitats on the planet. As an anthropogenic biotic invader, <jats:italic>Spartina alterniflora</jats:italic> Loisel. competes with native plants, threatens native ecosystems and coastal aquaculture, and may cause local biodiversity to decline. The distribution area of the exotic species <jats:italic>S. alterniflora</jats:italic> in the Yellow River Delta had been expanding to ca.4,000 ha from 1990 to 2018. In this study, we reported, for the first time, the competitive effects of the exotic plant (<jats:italic>S. alterniflora</jats:italic>) on seagrass (<jats:italic>Zostera japonica</jats:italic> Asch. & Graebn.) by field investigation and a transplant experiment in the Yellow River Delta. Within the first 3 months of the field experiment, <jats:italic>S. alterniflora</jats:italic> had pushed forward 14 m into the <jats:italic>Z. japonica</jats:italic> distribution region. In the study region, the area of <jats:italic>S. alterniflora</jats:italic> in 2019 increased by 516 times compared with its initial area in 2015. Inhibition of <jats:italic>Z. japonica</jats:italic> growth increased with the invasion of <jats:italic>S. alterniflora</jats:italic>. <jats:italic>Z. japonica</jats:italic> had been degrading significantly under the pressure of <jats:italic>S. alterniflora</jats:italic> invasion. <jats:italic>S. alterniflora</jats:italic> propagates sexually via seeds for long distance invasion and asexually by tillers and rhizomes for short distance invasion. Our results describe the invasion pattern of <jats:italic>S. alterniflora</jats:italic> and can be used to develop strategies for prevention and control of <jats:italic>S. alterniflora</jats:italic> invasion.</jats:p>
